# Trade winds

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to navigation Jump to search

This article is about the weather phenomenon. For other uses, see
[Tradewind](/wiki/Tradewind_\(disambiguation\) "Tradewind
\(disambiguation\)").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Map_prevailing_winds_on_earth.png/300px-
Map_prevailing_winds_on_earth.png)](/wiki/File:Map_prevailing_winds_on_earth.png)

[](/wiki/File:Map_prevailing_winds_on_earth.png "Enlarge")

The [westerlies](/wiki/Westerlies "Westerlies") (blue arrows) and trade winds
(yellow and brown arrows)

The **trade winds** are the [prevailing pattern](/wiki/Prevailing_winds
"Prevailing winds") of easterly surface [winds](/wiki/Wind "Wind") found in
the [tropics](/wiki/Tropics "Tropics"), within the lower portion of the
[Earth's atmosphere](/wiki/Earth%27s_atmosphere "Earth's atmosphere"), in the
lower section of the [troposphere](/wiki/Troposphere "Troposphere") near the
Earth's [equator](/wiki/Equator "Equator"). The trade winds blow predominantly
from the northeast in the [Northern Hemisphere](/wiki/Northern_Hemisphere
"Northern Hemisphere") and from the southeast in the [Southern
Hemisphere](/wiki/Southern_Hemisphere "Southern Hemisphere"), strengthening
during the winter and when the [Arctic oscillation](/wiki/Arctic_oscillation
"Arctic oscillation") is in its warm phase. Trade winds have been used by
captains of [sailing ships](/wiki/Sailing_ship "Sailing ship") to cross the
world's oceans for centuries, and enabled colonial expansion into the Americas
and trade routes to become established across the
[Atlantic](/wiki/Atlantic_ocean "Atlantic ocean") and [Pacific
oceans](/wiki/Pacific_ocean "Pacific ocean").

In [meteorology](/wiki/Meteorology "Meteorology"), the trade winds act as the
[steering flow](/wiki/Prevailing_winds "Prevailing winds") for [tropical
storms](/wiki/Tropical_storms "Tropical storms") that form over the Atlantic,
Pacific, and southern [Indian Oceans](/wiki/Indian_Ocean "Indian Ocean") and
make landfall in North America, Southeast Asia, and Madagascar and eastern
Africa, respectively. Trade winds also transport African dust westward across
the [Atlantic Ocean](/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean "Atlantic Ocean") into the
[Caribbean Sea](/wiki/Caribbean_Sea "Caribbean Sea"), as well as portions of
southeastern [North America](/wiki/North_America "North America"). Shallow
[cumulus clouds](/wiki/Cumulus_cloud "Cumulus cloud") are seen within trade
wind regimes, and are capped from becoming taller by a trade wind inversion,
which is caused by descending air aloft from within the [subtropical
ridge](/wiki/Subtropical_ridge "Subtropical ridge"). The weaker the trade
winds become, the more rainfall can be expected in the neighboring landmasses.

## Contents

  * 1 History
  * 2 Cause
  * 3 Weather effects
  * 4 See also
  * 5 References

## History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Trade_winds&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: History")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Spanish_Galleon.jpg/200px-
Spanish_Galleon.jpg)](/wiki/File:Spanish_Galleon.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Spanish_Galleon.jpg "Enlarge")

A Spanish galleon

See also: [Age of Discovery](/wiki/Age_of_Discovery "Age of Discovery"),
[Volta do Mar](/wiki/Volta_do_Mar "Volta do Mar"), and [Age of
sail](/wiki/Age_of_sail "Age of sail")

The term _trade winds_ originally derives from the early fourteenth century
late [Middle English](/wiki/Middle_English "Middle English") word 'trade,'
meaning "path" or "track."[1] The Portuguese recognized the importance of the
trade winds (then the _[Volta do mar](/wiki/Volta_do_mar "Volta do mar")_ ,
meaning in Portuguese "turn of the sea" but also "return from the sea") in
navigation in both the north and south Atlantic ocean as early as the 15th
century.[2] From West Africa, the Portuguese had to sail away from continental
Africa, that is, to west and northwest. They could then turn northeast, to the
area around the [Azores](/wiki/Azores "Azores") islands, and finally east to
mainland Europe. They also learned that to reach South Africa, they needed to
go far out in the ocean, head for Brazil, and around 30°S go east again.
Following the African coast southbound means upwind in the Southern
hemisphere. In the Pacific ocean, the full wind circulation, which included
both the trade wind easterlies and higher-latitude
[Westerlies](/wiki/Westerlies "Westerlies"), was unknown to Europeans until
[Andres de Urdaneta](/wiki/Andres_de_Urdaneta "Andres de Urdaneta")'s voyage
in 1565.[3]

The captain of a sailing ship seeks a course along which the winds can be
expected to blow in the direction of travel.[4] During the [Age of
Sail](/wiki/Age_of_Sail "Age of Sail"), the pattern of [prevailing
winds](/wiki/Prevailing_winds "Prevailing winds") made various points of the
globe easy or difficult to access, and therefore had a direct effect on
European empire-building and thus on modern political geography. For example,
[Manila galleons](/wiki/Manila_galleon "Manila galleon") could not sail into
the wind at all.[3]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Edmond_Halley%27s_map_of_the_trade_winds%2C_1686.jpg/275px-
Edmond_Halley%27s_map_of_the_trade_winds%2C_1686.jpg)](/wiki/File:Edmond_Halley%27s_map_of_the_trade_winds,_1686.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Edmond_Halley%27s_map_of_the_trade_winds,_1686.jpg "Enlarge")

[Edmond Halley](/wiki/Edmond_Halley "Edmond Halley")'s map of the trade winds,
1686

By the 18th century the importance of the trade winds to England's merchant
fleet for crossing the Atlantic Ocean had led both the general public and
etymologists to identify the name with a later meaning of 'trade', "(foreign)
commerce".[5] Between 1847 and 1849, [Matthew Fontaine
Maury](/wiki/Matthew_Fontaine_Maury "Matthew Fontaine Maury") collected enough
information to create wind and current charts for the world's oceans.[6]

## Cause[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Trade_winds&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: Cause")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Earth_Global_Circulation_-
_en.svg/400px-Earth_Global_Circulation_-
_en.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Earth_Global_Circulation_-_en.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Earth_Global_Circulation_-_en.svg "Enlarge")

3D map showing [Hadley cells](/wiki/Hadley_cell "Hadley cell") in relationship
to trade winds on the surface.

See also: [Air mass](/wiki/Air_mass "Air mass"), [Hadley
cell](/wiki/Hadley_cell "Hadley cell"), [Humidity](/wiki/Humidity "Humidity"),
[Intertropical Convergence Zone](/wiki/Intertropical_Convergence_Zone
"Intertropical Convergence Zone"), [Monsoon](/wiki/Monsoon "Monsoon"),
[Monsoon trough](/wiki/Monsoon_trough "Monsoon trough"), [Near-equatorial
trough](/wiki/Near-equatorial_trough "Near-equatorial trough"), and
[Prevailing winds](/wiki/Prevailing_winds "Prevailing winds")

As part of the [Hadley cell](/wiki/Hadley_cell "Hadley cell"), surface air
flows toward the equator while the flow aloft is towards the
[poles](/wiki/Geographic_pole "Geographic pole"). A [low-pressure
area](/wiki/Low-pressure_area "Low-pressure area") of calm, light variable
winds near the equator is known as the [doldrums](/wiki/Doldrums
"Doldrums"),[7] near-equatorial trough,[8] intertropical front, or the
[Intertropical Convergence Zone](/wiki/Intertropical_Convergence_Zone
"Intertropical Convergence Zone").[9] When located within a
[monsoon](/wiki/Monsoon "Monsoon") region, this zone of low pressure and wind
convergence is also known as the [monsoon trough](/wiki/Monsoon_trough
"Monsoon trough").[10] Around 30° in both hemispheres, air begins to descend
toward the surface in subtropical high-pressure belts known as [subtropical
ridges](/wiki/Subtropical_ridge "Subtropical ridge"). The subsident (sinking)
air is relatively dry because as it descends, the temperature increases, but
the absolute humidity remains constant, which lowers the relative humidity of
the air mass. This warm, dry air is known as a superior air mass and normally
resides above a maritime tropical (warm and moist) air mass. An increase of
temperature with height is known as a temperature inversion. When it occurs
within a trade wind regime, it is known as a trade wind inversion.[11]

The surface air that flows from these subtropical high-pressure belts toward
the Equator is deflected toward the west in both hemispheres by the [Coriolis
effect](/wiki/Coriolis_effect "Coriolis effect").[12] These winds blow
predominantly from the northeast in the [Northern
Hemisphere](/wiki/Northern_Hemisphere "Northern Hemisphere") and from the
southeast in the [Southern Hemisphere](/wiki/Southern_Hemisphere "Southern
Hemisphere").[13] Because winds are named for the direction from which the
wind is blowing,[14] these winds are called the northeasterly trade winds in
the Northern Hemisphere and the southeasterly trade winds in the Southern
Hemisphere. The trade winds of both hemispheres meet at the
[doldrums](/wiki/Doldrums "Doldrums").[7]

As they blow across tropical regions, air masses heat up over lower latitudes
due to more direct sunlight. Those that develop over land (continental) are
drier and hotter than those that develop over oceans (maritime), and travel
northward on the western periphery of the subtropical ridge.[15] Maritime
tropical air masses are sometimes referred to as trade air masses.[16] The one
region of the [Earth](/wiki/Earth "Earth") which has an absence of trade winds
is the north [Indian ocean](/wiki/Indian_ocean "Indian ocean").[17]

## Weather effects[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Trade_winds&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Weather effects")]

Clouds which form above regions within trade wind regimes are typically
composed of cumulus which extend no more than 4 kilometres (13,000 ft) in
height, and are capped from being taller by the trade wind inversion.[18]
Trade winds originate more from the direction of the poles (northeast in the
Northern Hemisphere, southeast in the Southern Hemisphere) during the cold
season, and are stronger in the winter than the summer.[19] As an example, the
windy season in the [Guianas](/wiki/Guyana "Guyana"), which lie at low
latitudes in [South America](/wiki/South_America "South America"), occurs
between January and April.[20] When the phase of the [Arctic
oscillation](/wiki/Arctic_oscillation "Arctic oscillation") (AO) is warm,
trade winds are stronger within the tropics. The cold phase of the AO leads to
weaker trade winds.[21] When the trade winds are weaker, more extensive areas
of rain fall upon landmasses within the tropics, such as [Central
America](/wiki/Central_America "Central America").[22]

During mid-summer in the Northern Hemisphere (July), the westward-moving trade
winds south of the northward-moving [subtropical
ridge](/wiki/Subtropical_ridge "Subtropical ridge") expand northwestward from
the [Caribbean sea](/wiki/Caribbean_sea "Caribbean sea") into southeastern
North America (Florida and Gulf Coast). When dust from the
[Sahara](/wiki/Sahara "Sahara") moving around the southern periphery of the
ridge travels over land, rainfall is suppressed and the sky changes from a
blue to a white appearance which leads to an increase in red sunsets. Its
presence negatively impacts [air quality](/wiki/Air_quality "Air quality") by
adding to the count of airborne particulates.[23] Although the Southeast USA
has some of the cleanest air in North America, much of the African dust that
reaches the United States affects Florida.[24] Since 1970, dust outbreaks have
worsened due to periods of drought in Africa. There is a large variability in
the dust transport to the Caribbean and Florida from year to year.[25] Dust
events have been linked to a decline in the health of [coral
reefs](/wiki/Coral_reef "Coral reef") across the Caribbean and Florida,
primarily since the 1970s.[26]
